Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Quantum Algorithms Arising from Ideas in Physics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Currently, quantum computers are able to manipulate no more than a few handfuls of qubits. However, it is widely expected that in the next few decades, quantum computers that are large enough to do interesting things will be built. Currently, the most lucrative application of these appear to be in the areas of cryptography and the areas of simulation of quantum mechanics, which it is hoped will have great impact in the areas of physics, chemistry, and pharmaceutical research. However, a toolbox of techniques for designing algorithms could give quantum computers a much greater impact, if algorithms could be developed for them that speed up other classes of problems, especially ones that speed up finding either the optimal or approximation solutions for combinatorial search problems.
The PIs intend to investigate several algorithms in quantum computing, approaching them by using ideas from physics, computer science, and mathematics. The PIs view quantum information science as a branch of all of these disciplines, and believe that techniques from each area can open insights into the others. The questions the PIs intend to address are related to algorithms and protocols: (1) exploration instances of adiabatic quantum algorithms where they outperform classical algorithms, (2) an in-depth study of knot-based quantum money schemes, (3) an attempt to solve quantum versions of the satisfiability problem, and (4) investigate quantum approximate optimization algorithms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The QAOA (Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm) is a quantum algorithm that was invented by PI Farhi. It is a top candidate for implementation on near-term quantum computers, as it does not require that these computers have extensive resources. The QAOA is a low-depth algorithm, which means that its computation time is short, so that errors do not have time to accumulate. Furthermore, simulations show that it appears to have some further error resistance beyond the error resistance it acquires simply by being low-depth.

Unfortunately, the QAOA has not been proven to be faster than classical algorithms for any specific problems. As a counterpart to this, Farhi and Aram Harrow provided evidence that there are problems that the QAOA can solve efficiently that are not amenable to attack by classical computers. More specifically, they showed that if classical computers can simulate the QAOA, then the polynomial hierarchy will collapse, something that theoretical computer scientists believe is extremely unlikely. 

PI Shor has been looking at quantum algorithms for dealing with high-dimensional lattices. Quantum computers can break the public-key cryptosystems currently in general use, so there is an urgent need to find post-quantum cryptosystems that cannot be broken by quantum computers to replace them.  Shor has been looking at different ways that quantum computers can be used to manipulate lattices. Finding as many such techniques as possible is desirable so that we have tools to test whether these cryptosystems can be broken by quantum computers, and further, to decide what parameters we should choose to make these cryptosystems secure. Shor’s attempt to break lattice cryptosystems was unsuccessful, but he has identified a number of ways to manipulate lattices on quantum computers, including a new lattice quantum Fourier transform that he discovered with coauthor Lior Eldar, as well as others that he discovered very recently.
